awd_titl_txt: Theoretical investigations of molecular collisions and chemical reactions at ultracold temperatures
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of techniques for cooling and trapping of a wide variety of atomic and molecular samples in recent years has created exciting opportunities for probing and manipulating chemical reactions at cold and ultracold temperatures. Theoretical studies of atomic and molecular interactions at cold and ultracold temperatures have become an integral part of this endeavor. To further advance progress in this field, quantitative calculations of rotational and vibrational transitions in cold and ultracold molecule collisions, including heteronuclear molecules, will be carried out by taking the H2-H2 and H2-HD systems as illustrative examples. In addition, quantum mechanical calculations will be carried out on the astrophysically important O+OH reaction at cold and ultracold temperatures. State-of-the-art quantum scattering methods will be used to investigate the molecule-molecule and atom-molecule collisions. General purpose computer codes have not been developed for this type of calculations. The molecule-molecule scattering calculations will be performed using a quantum scattering code jointly developed with Roman Krems (University of British Columbia) during the previous funding cycle. The code will be made available to the broader scientific community once it has been fully implemented and tested for the general case of diatom-diatom collisions. 

The studies will have broad impact on research at the interface between Atomic, Molecular and Optical (AMO) Physics, Physical Chemistry, and Astrochemistry. The computational algorithms developed will be equally applicable for molecular phenomena in related fields, for example, Atmospheric physics and Astrophysics. Summer support for an undergraduate student and partial support for a postdoctoral scholar will be provided to carry out research in the frontier area of AMO Physics. The postdoctoral scholar will be expected to take up a tenure track or similar position after completion of the work and to continue to mentor students and scholars.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to understand the behavior molecules, their interactions, and chemical reactivity at temperatures well below 1 K. In this regime, referred to as cold and ultracold temperatures, quantum effects become important and a quantum mechanical description is required to accurately describe molecular phenomena. We carried out explicit quantum scattering calculations of interactions between two hydrogen molecules to understand energy flow among rotational and vibrational motions of the molecules when the translational kinetic energy is very small (less than 1 K). This is a mathematical problem of considerable complexity and it required the development of new computational algorithms to solve the Schrödinger equation in six-dimensions. The same algorithm also enables study of similar processes involving other molecules at higher temperatures of interest atmospheric and astrophysical environments. Our study indicated that rotational and vibrational energy transfer occurs very efficiently in collisions of two hydrogen molecules when they are initially prepared in an excited vibrational or rotational level. The process becomes even more efficient when the energy and angular momentum gaps between the initial and final states are small. We examined energy transfer in collisions of many different molecules, including, CO, NH3, and H2O with collision partners H, He, and in some cases also H2. Some of these are very complex systems and required some approximations such as the rigid rotor model (fixed bond lengths for the molecule) to make the quantum calculations practical, especially for the non-linear NH3 and H2O molecules. Results of these studies are also relevant to molecular issues in astrophysics and some of our findings are published in the Astrophysical Journal.

Since chemical reaction involves rearrangement scattering (making and breaking of chemical bonds in the traditional sense) a different set of tools are required for theoretical investigation of chemical reaction dynamics. Our study applied to chemical reactions involving hydroxyl radicals and atomic oxygen revealed that weak van der Waals forces that normally do not influence reactivity at ordinary temperatures play a significant role in the cold and ultracold regimes. By altering the strength of these interactions by an external electric and/or magnetic field, it becomes possible to control the outcome of a chemical reaction at sub-Kelvin temperatures. Quantum control of chemical reactions is an area of active research and cold and ultracold molecules provide interesting opportunities for both theoretical and experimental investigations of this process.

In the course of these investigations, we trained three postdoctoral scholars and four undergraduate students. One undergraduate student is co-author of a peer-reviewed publication resulting from this work. He is planning to go to medical school. Another undergraduate student is pursuing PhD in Biochemistry at Penn State University. A third undergraduate student is employed at a drug discovery firm in San Diego. Altogether, 11 peer-reviewed journal publications, two book chapters, and over a dozen conference proceedings resulted from this project. It also led to new computational algorithms that enable quantum mechanical investigations of molecular phenomena in diverse environments.
